speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Right now, we're experimenting with three layers.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The top layer is a high-level planner using active inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Using the active inference controller, this layer updates belief using variation of free energy and performs planning using the expected free energy.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: where does the expected free energy, all those information comes, we need to sample many different possible trajectories.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So that's how we move to the second layer, the diffusion projector.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Our diffusion projector learns from dataset and from past experience to generate possible paths.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The high-level active inference layer will select a preferred region, some kind of points or area or distribution, as we refer to G-distribution.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: that belief gets passed on to the diffusion planner.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And the diffusion planner generates many possible trajectories to that region.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And at this point, the actual goal hasn't been found yet.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We are still looking for the goal.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But we are generating diverse trajectory towards that most probable region.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And these trajectories consist of a sequence of waypoints and corresponding states that represent the possible paths.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And then, obviously, we calculate the expected free energy and then select the best possible trajectory.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And once we have the trajectory, now we have the low-level controller.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The low-level controller is just a lightweight, small-scale reinforcement learning controller that generates actions to connect the small waypoints.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So by having this hierarchical structure, we believe we can solve this problem much faster than the original literature, where Dr. Snyder solved this problem with model predictive control with active inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: If you run that, it takes tremendous amounts of planning time and learning time, and we believe by
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: because of the nature of diffusion process, we can make this learning process and planning process much faster.
